Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 06:45AM Raysgirl wrote: Hi there, I too am new to this forum. We unfortunately are in this club together.  I was first diagnosed at 38 and was Stage IIa...and after all of the surgery and treatment thought I was over my cancer experience.  But alas, the universe had a different plan.  6 years to the day, I was diagnosed with bone mets this past August.  First on Femera, Zometa and Fosladex.  Not much improvement so we switched the Femera to Aromasin last month.  No real side effects from any of it and going just once a month isn't too intrusive into my real life.  I log onto this site when I am feeling down and scared because I feel inspired by the posts of people who are where I am.  I am not into in person support groups but this virtual one is comforting.  I use an acronym type mantra to keep me going...ADAPT - Adapt(cause I have to),Determined, Attitude, Perserverance, Trust...if it resonates with you feel free to use!
Posts.Title: bone metastisis mimi73 LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2009 08:11AM Raysgirl wrote: Heidi, as someone said to me when I first logged on, welcome to the club no one wants to join.  I had the steroids as well when I had taxol.  I loved them as they gave me tons of energy.  As far as the port goes, I refused to get one when first treated when I was a Stage II in 2001.  I have been Stage IV for 18 months and recently had to start IV chemo.  I was resistant to getting the port but was gently persauded by my onc team and family.  I am glad I did.  The procedure to put it in was no big deal, after the first shot of valium, I was out cold, and the scar is really small. This sucks big time for us all but there is a lot of support on this site and a lot of hope when you see how long woman have been living with Stage IV.
Posts.Title: New Sister Arrival Heidi_Ho 33skidoo

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 06:46AM Raysgirl wrote: Pee, I am with you...didn't get a port the first time around, 7 years ago.  But I am scheduled to have a power port put in on Monday...between the onc., the nurses and my family, I gave in...really didn't want to have yet another scar.  So, I appreciate this post, makes me feel better.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Need some input on ports...please... pee wallflower

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 05:29PM Raysgirl wrote: I echo everyones comments about welcome but sorry you ave to be here.  Just a suggestion to bring someone with you to the appts who will take notes and to write down questions before you go so you can make the most of the appointments.  This can all be very overwhelming and I have found that having everything written down helps and provides me the opportunity to review later and ask questions that I hadn't thought of while talking to the doctors.
Posts.Title: New here virginiamom Mazy1959

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 09:32AM Raysgirl wrote: Peggyr7,  you may want to look on this board for other discussions regarding the meeting in Boston.  I think some of the ladies were planning on going.  As to advocacy and education, I do agree Stage IV folks like us have been in the shadows of the pink parades...I just watched the movie Milk (Sean Penn just won the Academy Award for best actor) and it was really about the gays coming out of the closet and demanding equal rights.  It made me think about the fact that we always herar about early detection etc and a cure which makes sense but you really never hear anyone talking about what we are going through...I guess the mbcnetwork is working to change that. It only takes one passionate person to get a movement going...maybe it is you!
Posts.Title: MBCNetwork conference peggyr7 Raysgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 01:12PM Raysgirl wrote: I am sorry to hear of the results...FYI, I was on a morphine drip for 2 days and after that I didn't have to take anything for the pain...they get you up and moving right away.  Last minute they told me that a vascular surgeon was going to put a "filter" in a vein to help reduce the risk of blood clots so you may want to ask about that (after they put me out but before the surgery)  Hang in there and heal so you can dance in the spring rain.  If you have any questions about the procedure etc., just ask.
Posts.Title: fracture shows reason for pain--any suggestions? lv2cmp meima-Bev

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 04:25PM Raysgirl wrote: I too just started Gemzar.  I had 2 treatments and then had this week off.  My platelets and hemoglobin have dropped but not to the point where we will skip treatment.  Have a bit of nausea and stomach upset but not too bad.  In the last few days, I am experiencing hair loss.  They said it should thin but I shouldn't lose it all..anyone else have any experience with hair loss on Gemzar?
Posts.Title: Gemzar janmarie LindaYO

Posts.Content: May 24, 2009 11:22AM Raysgirl wrote: You have had a lot to deal with in a short amount of time.  And you have every right to feel what you are feeling.  I agree w/Janis...don't be a martyr...get the drugs to minimize the side effects.  I also strongly recommend anti-depressants...once I got on the right dose, it made dealing with all of this crap much easier.  I was spending so much energy on trying not to be sad and mad that I didn't have any energy for anything else, like living. Now I still have those emotions, I sit with them for a bit and then move on...I don't spiral down and put my head under the covers anymore.  With time you will figure out a way to manage the ups and downs. I also allowed people who wanted to help me, to do so.  My mother quotes me as having said, "I'll do it myself, mother" when I was little and thats the way I have always been.  But giving people the opportunity to show you that they love you is good for them and good for you.  You will find your way and coming to this forum for inspiration along the way will serve you well.
Posts.Title: Started chemo, is this it from now on? PattyP bmdaley

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 01:51PM Raysgirl wrote: Just wanted to provide you with my recent experience relative the the impending fracture. I woke up in October without being able to put any weight on my right leg. Test revealed a stress fracture.  So, I stayed off of it as much as possible, used a cane/walker and the pain went away, but the leg felt weak.  Additional tests one month later revealed a fracture in the femoral neck.  In my case (and our cases may be very different) he suggested a partial hip replacement.  After getting a second opinion which confirmed the diagnosis, I scheduled surgery for Jan. 6 (great way to start the new year).  Again, in my case, I couldn't walk without assistance and I didn't want to stay that way.  The info from the doctor was that its better to catch the fracture while still "impending" to not wait to deal with it once it actually does fracture.  But, thats what I would ask, what happens if I do nothing.  If you go to a surgeon, they usually suggest surgery, right?  I also went to a orthopeadic oncologist, rather than a regular one and I felt like I was in better hands. BTW, I have borrowed your quote above and shared it with my husband and we do try to figure out how to dance in the rain.  So, thanks for that.  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: fracture shows reason for pain--any suggestions? lv2cmp meima-Bev

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 07:19PM Raysgirl wrote: I do know how you feel.  I had partial hip replacement in January have been housebound for much of the time since.  I had a similar thought during the recuperation, once I am better, I am still going to have cancer...being stuck in the house with too much time on my hands to think is not a good thing.   So, I am just starting to get out more.  I am forcing myself to engage with the rest of the world rather than isolate myself...you are lucky to have such great friends, it sounds like a fun weekend.  There is a line from Shawshank Redemption (sp?)...I am either going to get busy dying or get busy living...so, go have a great time and get busy living.  I too, will take my advice!
Posts.Title: I want my social life back! marshakb LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 07:15AM Raysgirl wrote: It is a bisphosphonate with the intention of building back bone loss...you should ask your  onc if he/she wants you to take calcium supplements as well.  The infusion is 15 minutes for me...and I have not had any side effects at all.  I am on it every other month...hang in and good luck with the surgery.
Posts.Title: What´s the scoop on Zometa? pitanga HeleneS

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2009 09:50AM Raysgirl wrote: I recently went through a similar experience...I had hip replacement surgery in January and have been limited in my mobility for a few months before and till now although it is getting better, my scans showed progression which required me to go on IV chemo instead of pills...and my employer likes to kick a dog when they are down and instead of accommodation my disability they essentially forced me to go out on STD and I am now pursuing LTD as well At some point for us it becomes too much to bear and you can only see the negative.  After continuous gentle prodding from the people who love me, I saw the shrink at the Cancer Institute, they increased my anti-depression meds and I began to force myself to make plans...and I am feeling better...but it takes time and putting too much pressure on your Mom may make it worse.  I joke with my family that they had an intervention but essentially, they all reached out to me in different ways, always with love and didn't force...they had my onc call to express his concern, mom sent emails with her suggestions along with a comment that she can see me rolling my eyes, friends called and said they were going to pop in just for 30 minutes as they passed by, my brother made my favorite foods and invited me for dinner, my sister choreographed this whole thing and my husband was at my side prodding and encouraging...I knew what they were all doing but at the same time didn't feel pressure to perform so to speak.  Often, we feel disconnected with other people who are not in cancerland and feel very alone, some of the above made me realize that while they can't fix this, having them around and doing things I like to do can ease the pain...that and the meds of course, haha Hope this helps - oh, I also started visiting this site more often and it made me feel less isolated and reading/engaging with people who have been Stage IV for many times longer than me provided encouragement as well...
Posts.Title: Anxiety and Depression Survive YHong
